revision.text: {{for|the tendency of saliva to flow out of the mouth|drooling}} {{Infobox software | name = Drools | logo = | caption = | developer = [[Red Hat]] | latest release version = 7.9.0.Final | latest release date = {{release date and age|2018|07|27}} | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | programming language = [[Java (programming language)|Java]] | genre = [[Rules engine]] | license = [[Apache License|ASL 2]] }} '''Drools''' is a [[business rule management system]] (BRMS) with a [[forward chaining|forward]] and [[backward chaining]] inference based [[rules engine]], more correctly known as a [[Production system (computer science)|production rule system]], using an enhanced implementation of the [[Rete algorithm]]. KIE (Knowledge Is Everything) is the new umbrella name to drools, [[optaPlanner]], [[jBPM]], Guvnor, uberFire and related technologies. Drools supports the Java Rules Engine API (Java Specification Request 94) standard for its [[business rule]] engine and enterprise framework for the construction, maintenance, and enforcement of business policies in an organization, application, or service. == JBoss Enterprise BRMS == '''JBoss Enterprise BRMS''' is a [[business rule management system]] and [[reasoning engine]] for business policy and rules development, access, and change management.{{cite web|title=JBoss Enterprise BRMS|url=http://www.jboss.com/products/platforms/brms/|publisher=[[Red Hat]]}} JBoss Enterprise BRMS is a productized version of '''Drools''' with enterprise-level support available. '''JBoss Rules''' is also a productized version of Drools, but JBoss Enterprise BRMS is the flagship product.{{cite web|title=JBoss Enterprise BRMS: Answers to frequently asked questions|url=http://www.jboss.com/pdf/brms-faq.pdf|publisher=JBoss Community}} Components of the enterprise version:{{cite web |title=JBoss Enterprise BRMS Platform 5.1 |url=http://www.jboss.com/products/platforms/brms/components/ |publisher=[[Red Hat]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110318221503/http://www.jboss.com/products/platforms/brms/components/ |archivedate=2011-03-18 |df= }} * [[JBoss Enterprise Application Platform#Related products|JBoss Enterprise Web Platform]] – the software infrastructure, supported to run the BRMS components only * [[JBoss Enterprise Application Platform]] or [[JBoss Enterprise SOA Platform]] – the software infrastructure, supported to run the BRMS components only * Business Rules Engine – Drools Expert using the [[Rete algorithm]] and the Drools Rule Language (DRL){{cite web|title=JBoss Enterprise BRMS datasheet|url=http://www.jboss.com/pdf/JBossBRMSFactSheetWebPDF.pdf|publisher=[[Red Hat]]|page=4}} * Business Rules Manager – Drools Guvnor - Guvnor is a centralised repository for Drools Knowledge Bases, with rich web based GUIs, editors, and tools to aid in the management of large numbers of rules.http://www.jboss.org/drools/drools-guvnor * Business Rules Repository – Drools Guvnor '''Drools''' and '''Guvnor''' are JBoss Community open source projects. As they are mature, they are brought into the enterprise-ready product JBoss Enterprise BRMS. Components of the JBoss Community version:{{cite web|title=Drools 5 - The Business Logic integration Platform|url=http://www.jboss.org/drools|publisher=JBoss Community}} * Drools Guvnor (Business Rules Manager) – a centralized repository for Drools Knowledge Bases * Drools Expert (rule engine) – uses the rules to perform reasoning * Drools Flow (process/workflow), or [[Jbpm5|jBPM 5]] – provides for workflow and business processes * Drools Fusion (event processing/temporal reasoning) – provides for [[complex event processing]] * Drools Planner/[[OptaPlanner]] (automated planning) – optimizes automated planning, including [[NP-hard]] planning problems == Example == This examplehttp://downloads.jboss.com/drools/docs/5.1.1.34858.FINAL/drools-expert/html_single/index.html#d0e2676{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} illustrates a simple rule to print out information about a holiday in July. It checks a condition on an instance of the Holiday class, and executes Java code if that condition is true. rule "validate holiday" dialect "mvel" dialect "java" when $h1 : Holiday( month == "july" ) then System.out.println($h1.name + ":" + $h1.month); end The purpose of dialect "mvel" is to point the Getter and Setters of the variables of your [[Plain Old Java Object]] (POJO) classes. Consider the above example, in which a Holiday class is used and inside the circular brackets (parentheses) "month" is used. So with the help dialect "mvel" the getter and setters of the variable "month" can be accessed. Dialect "java" is used to help us write our Java code in our rules. There is one restriction or characteristic on this. We cannot use Java code inside "when" part of the rule but we can use Java code in "then" part. We can also declare a Reference variable $h1 without the $ symbol. There is no restriction on this. The main purpose of putting the $ symbol before the variable is to mark the difference between variables of POJO classes and Rules. == Related systems == * [[CLIPS]]: [[public domain software]] tool for building expert systems. * [[Corticon]]: a rule engine for Java and .NET. * [[Jess programming language|JESS]]: a rule engine for the Java platform - it is a superset of [[CLIPS]] programming language. * [[Prolog]]: a general purpose logic programming language. * [[OpenL Tablets]]: business centric rules and BRMS. * Gandalf: open-source decision engine on PHP. * [[DTRules]]: a Decision Table-based, open-sourced rule engine for Java. * [[Oracle Policy Automation]]: a suite of software products for modeling and deploying business rules within enterprise applications * [[IBM Operational Decision Management]]: IBM's BRMS and event processing product * [[InRule Technology]]: Business Rules Management System ==See also== {{Portal|Free Software|Java (programming language)}} * [[List of JBoss software]] * [[Semantic reasoner]] * [[WildFly]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website}} {{Prone to spam|date=November 2018}} {{Z148}} [[Category:Rule engines]] [[Category:Red Hat software]] [[Category:Free software programmed in Java (programming language)]] [[category:logic]]

page.title: Electricity (Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark song)

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox song | name = Electricity | cover = Electricity.gif | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark]] | album = [[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark (album)|Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark]] | B-side = Almost | released = 21 May 1979 | format = [[Gramophone record|7" vinyl]] | recorded = {{unbulleted list|[[Cargo Studios]], [[Rochdale]]|Henry's Studio, [[Liverpool]]}} | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[New wave music|New wave]]<ref>{{cite web|title= Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark |publisher= [[Douban]] |quote= this is the first album by Orchestral Manoeuvres In The Dark, first released on Virgin in 1980. 10 tracks, including the new wave hits 'Messages' and 'Electricity'. |url= http://music.douban.com/subject/1613993/ |accessdate= 23 June 2013}}</ref>|[[synthpop]]<ref name="NR"/>}} | length = 3:32 | label = {{unbulleted list|[[Factory Records|Factory]] – <small>FAC 6</small> (1st release)|[[Dindisc]] (2nd & 3rd releases)}} | writer = {{hlist|[[Paul Humphreys]]|[[Andy McCluskey]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[Martin Hannett|Martin Zero]]|Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark|Chester Valentino}} | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = [[Red Frame/White Light]] | next_year = 1980 }}
"'''Electricity'''" is the 1979 debut single of the English group [[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark]], featured on their [[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark (album)|eponymous debut album]] the following year. Inspired by [[Kraftwerk]]'s "[[Radioactivity (song)|Radioactivity]]",<ref>{{cite web|title= Electricity by OMD |publisher= Songfacts |url= http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=17624 |accessdate= 23 July 2013}}</ref> the song addresses society's wasteful usage of energy sources. [[Andy McCluskey]] and [[Paul Humphreys]] sing the lead vocals on the track together in unison. As with single "[[Messages (Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark song)|Messages]]" from the same album, the song features a melodic synth break instead of a sung chorus.<ref>{{cite web|title= Interview: Andy McCluskey, OMD |date= 19 March 2013 |publisher= [[PRS for Music]] |accessdate= 1 October 2013 |quote= Many of our songs use the synth melody as the chorus. There are verses but generally the melody is the chorus. |url= http://www.m-magazine.co.uk/creators/interview-andy-mcluskey-omd/}}</ref>
It was on the strength of "Electricity" that the band were offered a [[recording contract]] with [[Dindisc]],<ref>''Synth Britannia''. [[BBC Four]]. 16 October 2009.</ref> who twice re-issued the single. In 2012, "Electricity" peaked at no. 126 in the [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|French charts]].<ref>{{cite web|title= lescharts.com – OMD (Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark) – Electricity |url= http://lescharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=OMD+%28Orchestral+Manoeuvres+In+The+Dark%29&titel=Electricity&cat=s |publisher= Lescharts.com. Hung Medien |accessdate= 23 June 2013}}</ref>
[[Vince Clarke]] of [[Erasure]] (and formerly chief songwriter of [[Depeche Mode]], [[Yazoo (band)|Yazoo]] and [[The Assembly]]) has cited "Electricity" as his primary inspiration to pursue a career in electronic music,<ref name="ozone">{{cite episode|title= Erasure |series= [[The O-Zone]] |network= [[BBC Two|BBC 2]] |minutes= 8 |airdate= 29 November 1995 |station= [[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]] |quote= When I was 18 or 19 I heard a single called 'Electricity' by Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark. It sounded so different from anything I'd heard; that really made me want to make electronic music, 'cause it was so unique.}}</ref> while [[BBC Radio]]'s [[Steve Lamacq]] has named it as the track that made him want to become a [[Disc jockey|DJ]].<ref name="lamacq">{{cite magazine|first= Steve |last= Lamacq |authorlink= Steve Lamacq |title= Soundtrack of My Life |magazine= [[NME]] |date= 1 March 2014 |page= 25}}</ref>
==Track listing== # "Electricity" # "Almost"
==History== After OMD's first concert, opening for [[Joy Division]] in a 1978 appearance at [[Eric's Club]] in Liverpool, McCluskey was inspired to send a demo of the song to [[Factory Records]] founder [[Tony Wilson]]. They later heard that while he was not impressed with it, his wife was, so he bought it from them and released it as a single. Its ensuing success led to them receiving a seven-album record deal worth £250,000.<ref>{{cite news|first= Hugo |last= Lindgren |title= O.M.D.'s Plot Against Rock |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |date= 19 May 2013 |accessdate= 19 May 2013 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/12/magazine/omds-plot-against-rock.html}}</ref>
==Reception== "Electricity" was a hit with veteran [[Disk jockey|DJ]] [[John Peel]], who gave the song regular play on his late-night radio show;<ref name="lamacq"/><ref name="messages">{{cite book|first1= Johnny |last1= Waller |first2= Mike |last2= Humphreys |title= Messages |year= 1987 |publisher= [[Sidgwick & Jackson]] |page= 49 |isbn= 0-283-99234-4}}</ref> as a result, the British music press quickly picked up on the song.<ref name="messages"/> Adrian Thrills in the ''[[NME|New Musical Express]]'' cited it as "the best example of [[Factory Records]] to date – excellent, melodic, synthesiser pop." He also lauded B-side "Almost", calling it "a doleful, heartsick slab of electronic angst."<ref name="messages"/>
Conversely, [[Garry Bushell]] gave a negative review in ''[[Sounds (magazine)|Sounds]]'', in which he remarked: "If [[Mike Oldfield]] was ten years younger and a [[Tubeway Army]] fan, this is what he'd sound like – who wants to listen to a bunch of [[Scouse]]rs whining about electricity anyway?"<ref name="messages"/> However, [[David Hepworth]], who re-appraised the track in the same publication, opined that OMD's sound "commands your attention" and lauded the single for being "packaged with as much taste as it's played."<ref name="messages"/> "Electricity" featured on the ''NME'' end-of-year list for 1979.<ref>{{cite web|title= NME End of Year Lists 1979 |url= http://www.rocklistmusic.co.uk/1979.html |work= [[NME]] |publisher= Rocklist.net |accessdate= 23 July 2013}}</ref>
Retrospectively, [[AllMusic]] critic Ned Raggett described the song as "pure zeitgeist, a celebration of synth pop's incipient reign".<ref name="NR">{{cite web|first= Ned |last= Raggett |title= Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark – Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark |publisher= [[AllMusic]]. [[All Media Network]] |accessdate= 23 June 2013 |url= http://www.allmusic.com/album/orchestral-manoeuvres-in-the-dark-mw0000202497}}</ref> Colleague Dave Thompson called it a "perfect electro-pop number".<ref>{{cite web|first= Dave |last= Thompson |title= Electricity – Song Review |publisher= AllMusic. All Media Network |url= https://www.allmusic.com/song/electricity-mt0013639162 |accessdate= 23 July 2013}}</ref>
[[Vince Clarke]] cited "Electricity" as the track that sparked his interest in electronic music. In a [[BBC]] interview he said: "When I was 18 or 19 I heard a single called 'Electricity' by Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark. It sounded so different from anything I'd heard; that really made me want to make electronic music, 'cause it was so unique."<ref name="ozone"/> [[Simple Minds]] frontman [[Jim Kerr]] admitted to being "downright jealous" of the song.<ref>{{cite news|first= Andy |last= Coleman |title= A Simple concept |newspaper= [[Birmingham Mail]] |publisher= [[The Free Library]] |date= 27 November 2009 |accessdate= 4 May 2016 |url= http://www.thefreelibrary.com/A+Simple+concept%3B+USB+idea+will+help+Birmingham+concert+stick+in+the...-a0213045763}}</ref>
=="Electricity" and "Almost" versions== Multiple versions of "Electricity" exist; the earliest are recordings by McCluskey and Humphreys' previous group [[The Id]].
There are many different versions of the two songs that were present on OMD's debut single. After the band left [[Factory Records]], DinDisc attempted twice to score a hit with "Electricity". Consequently, four versions of "Electricity" and three of "Almost" exist.
;Version I *"Electricity" (3:36) and "Almost" (3:50) were originally recorded at [[Cargo Studios]], Rochdale and produced by [[Martin Hannett]] under the [[Nickname|moniker]] Martin Zero, to be released by [[Factory Records]].
;Version II *The band felt Hannett had overproduced their songs somewhat, so they recorded new versions at Henry's Studio, Liverpool. These versions were produced by themselves and band manager [[Paul Collister]] under the moniker Chester Valentino. *A compromise was reached for the versions used on the single. This first Factory single contains the band's version of "Electricity" (3:44) and the Hannett version of "Almost" (3:50).<ref name="OWD1">{{cite web|title= Official OMD website discography entry for first issue. |accessdate= 22 December 2007 |url= http://www.omd.uk.com/discography/singles/html/s_1.html |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/69itoRWxk?url=http://www.omd.uk.com/discography/singles/html/s_1.html |archivedate= 6 August 2012}}</ref> *Version II of "Almost" (3:43) remained unreleased until appearing on the 2001 compilation; ''[[Navigation: The OMD B-Sides]]''.
;Version III *The [[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark (album)|album]] versions of "Electricity" (3:39) and "Almost" (3:44) differ from the previous versions, and were used for the third and final release of the single. "Electricity" was remixed from the original Hannett version. It's also the version used on the 1988 ''[[The Best of OMD|Best Of]]'' and the 1998 ''[[The OMD Singles|Singles]]'' collections and is the best-known version of the song. The album version of "Almost" is similarly a remix of Hannett's version.
;Version IV ("Electricity" only) *A fourth mix of "Electricity" (3:43) was produced by [[Mike Howlett]]. This version of "Electricity" was recorded during the ''[[Organisation (album)|Organisation]]'' sessions when the band fancied extending the instrumental section in the middle of the song. It was initially released on the ''Dindisc 1980'' compilation album in 1980.<ref>{{cite web|title= Official OMD website discography - Compilations: DINDISC 1980 |accessdate= 17 April 2010 |url= http://www.omd.uk.com/discography/comps/html/done.html}}</ref> In 2003, it was released on CD as a bonus track on the re-issue of ''[[Organisation (album)|Organisation]]''.
;The Micronauts Remix *A radical remix by dance music act [[The Micronauts]] was released in 1998 both as part of ''[[The OMD Remixes]]'' release and as part of the bonus disc of the special edition ''[[The OMD Singles]]'' (France only).
==Cover versions== "Electricity" has been covered by the bands [[NOFX]]<ref>{{cite web|first= Jo-Ann |last= Greene |title= NOFX – 45 or 46 Songs That Weren't Good Enough to Go on Our Other Records |publisher= AllMusic. All Media Network |accessdate= 14 November 2016 |url= http://www.allmusic.com/album/45-or-46-songs-that-werent-good-enough-to-go-on-our-other-records-mw0000218642}}</ref> and [[MGMT]].<ref>{{cite magazine|first= Marc |last= Hogan |title= See MGMT Play 'Alien' New Song, Cover OMD Live in Bogota |magazine= [[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] |date= 2 April 2012 |accessdate= 14 November 2016 |url= http://www.spin.com/2012/04/see-mgmt-play-alien-new-song-cover-omd-live-bogota/}}</ref>
==Release history== ===Singles=== The following singles were released:
{|class="wikitable" !align="left" valign="top"|Date !align="left" valign="top"|Catalogue !align="left" valign="top"|"Electricity" !align="left" valign="top"|"Almost" !align="left" valign="top" width="300"|Sleeve !align="left" valign="top" width="240"|Notes |- |align="left" valign="top"|21 May 1979 |align="left" valign="top"|Factory FAC6 |align="left" valign="top"|Version II |align="left" valign="top"|Version I |align="left" valign="top"|Special 'black on black' sleeve, limited to 5000 copies. |align="left" valign="top"|OMD's first single.<ref name="OWD1"/> |- |align="left" valign="top"|28 September 1979 |align="left" valign="top"|DinDisc DIN2 |align="left" valign="top"|Version I |align="left" valign="top"|Version I |align="left" valign="top"|Standard [[Light-on-dark color scheme|white on black]] printing, with studio details on back of sleeve. |align="left" valign="top"|The single is re-released to coincide with the band signing to DinDisc.<ref>{{cite web|title= Official OMD website discography entry for second issue |url= http://www.omd.uk.com/discography/singles/html/s_2.html |accessdate= 22 December 2007}}</ref> |- |align="left" valign="top"|31 March 1980 |align="left" valign="top"|DinDisc DIN2 |align="left" valign="top"|Version III |align="left" valign="top"|Version III |align="left" valign="top"|Standard white on black printing, without studio details on back of sleeve. |align="left" valign="top"|Third attempt at achieving a hit. |}
===Albums=== "Electricity" and "Almost" were released on the following OMD albums:
{|class="wikitable" !Date !Album !Song !Version !Notes |- |rowspan="2" valign="top"|22 February 1980 |rowspan="2" valign="top"|''[[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark (album)|Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark]]'' |"Electricity" |Version III | |- |"Almost" |Version III | |- |rowspan="2" valign="top"|12 March 1988 |rowspan="2" valign="top"|''[[The Best of OMD]]'' |"Electricity" |Version III | |- |"Electricity" |[[music video]] |on the [[VHS]] version of the album |- |28 September 1998 |''[[The OMD Singles]]'' |"Electricity" |Version III | |- |24 April 2000 |''[[Peel Sessions 1979–1983]]'' |"Electricity" |Version II |Bonus track, subtitled "Factory Version 1979" |- |14 May 2001 |''[[Navigation: The OMD B-Sides]]'' |"Almost" |Version II | Subtitled "Alternate Version" |- |December 2002 |''[[The Id#EP|The Id]]'' |"Electricity" | |A 1978 recording by [[The Id]], the pre-OMD band. |- |rowspan="4" valign="top"|10 March 2003 |rowspan="4" valign="top"|''[[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark (album)|Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark]]'' reissue |"Electricity" |Version III | |- |"Almost" |Version III | |- |"Electricity" |Version I |Bonus track, subtitled "Hannett/Cargo Studios Version" |- |"Almost" |Version I |Bonus track, subtitled "Hannett/Cargo Studios Version" |- |10 March 2003 |''[[Organisation (album)|Organisation]]'' reissue |"Electricity" |Version IV |Bonus track, subtitled "Dindisc 1980 Version" |- |rowspan="2" valign="top"|10 March 2003 |rowspan="2" valign="top"|''[[Messages: Greatest Hits]]'' |"Electricity" |Version III | |- |"Electricity" |music video | |}
==Sleeve design== The sleeve was designed by Factory's designer [[Peter Saville (graphic designer)|Peter Saville]]. The band and Saville met in a Rochdale pub and exchanged ideas. Saville told them about a book of avant-garde musical scores which he'd come across. Andy McCluskey said that he sometimes wrote down the tunes he composed in a similar shorthand. This led to the unusual graphics that feature on the sleeve. Saville suggested to use shiny black ink on black paper. Neither OMD nor [[Tony Wilson]] believed it could be done, but Saville persuaded a printer to do the job. The [[thermographic printing]] was a success, but the place set on fire three times, so eventually only 5,000 sleeves were printed.<ref>{{cite journal|title= Industrial Manoeuvres in the Art |first= Steve |last= Taylor |magazine= [[The Face (magazine)|The Face]] |date= February 1981 |issue= 10 |pages= 50–53 |issn= 0263-1210}}</ref> The reissue sleeves were standard white on black printed sleeves.

'''Eleftherios Goulielmakis''' (Ελευθέριος Γουλιελμάκης) is a [[Greeks|Greek]] physicist specializing in [[laser]]s.{{Infobox scientist | name = Eleftherios Goulielmakis | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1975|05|18}} | birth_place = [[Heraklion, Crete, Greece]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = Hellenic | fields = [[Attosecond Physics]]
[[Ultrafast Science]] | workplaces = [[University of Rostock, Germany]], [[Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics, Germany]], [[Technical University of Vienna, Austria]] | alma_mater = [[Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität]]
[[University of Crete]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = Measurement of light field, Synthesis of light waves | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | footnotes = | ethnicity = | religion = }} He is a professor of physics at the University of Rostock, Germany and the head of the research group "Attoelectronics" at the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics in Garching, Germany. For his work on the [[attosecond]] control and synthesis of light waves he has been awarded the Georgios Foteinos ([[:el:Γεώργιος Φωτεινός]]) Prize of the [[Academy of Athens (modern)|Academy of Athens]] in 2007,[http://www.patris.gr Διεθνές βραβείο σε Ηρακλειώτη νέο επιστήμονα] Jun 28, 2010 – Ελευθέριος Γουλιελμάκης, ο οποίος διακρίθηκε με το βραβείο Νέου ... Φωτεινού της Ακαδημίας Αθηνών" (Βραβείο Γεωργίου Θ. Φωτεινού) the [[International Union of Pure and Applied Physics]] Young Scientist Prize in Optics of the [[International Commission for Optics]] in 2009, the [https://www.dpg-physik.de/preise/preistraeger_gh.html?lang=en& Gustav Hertz Prize] of the [[Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft]] (DPG) in 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.mpq.mpg.de/cms/mpq/en/news/awards/archiv/2012/12_11_19.html|title=Gustav Hertz Prize of DPG for Dr. Eleftherios Goulielmakis|accessdate=July 1, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130701101550/http://www.mpq.mpg.de/cms/mpq/en/news/awards/archiv/2012/12_11_19.html|archivedate=July 1, 2013|df=}}{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/17493447|title=Exciting electrons|work=[[The Economist]]|date=November 22, 2010|accessdate=July 1, 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/2010/aug/12/electrons-caught-moving-on-the-edge|title=Electrons caught moving on the edge|work=[[Physics World]]|date=August 12, 2010|accessdate=July 1, 2013}}Laser Focus World -2008 Volume 44, Issues 7-12 - Page 20 " the electric field of a laser pulse that rises from zero to its maximum value only within a few hundred attoseconds performs the streaking," says Eleftherios Goulielmakis, project leader at the Laboratory of Attosecond and High-field Physics at ..."''[[New Scientist]]'' Volume 186, Issues 2493-2501 2005 - Page 36 "Eleftherios Goulielmakis and others in Krausz's group at the Vienna University of Technology in Austria and the University of Bielefeld in Germany sent a light wave into a chamber of neon gas. Along with the light wave, they sent in an ...[http://www.ellines.com/en/erga-ellinon/3976-sunthetei-ta-kumata-tou-fotos/ Synthesizing waves of light] Retrieved July 1, 2013.[http://www.axortagos.gr/eleftherios-goulielmakis-ellinas-pou-diaprepei-sti-germania.html Ελευθέριος Γουλιελμάκης: Ο Έλληνας που διαπρέπει στη Γερμανία] November 28, 2012. Retrieved July 1, 2013. and the [[:de:Röntgen-Preis|Roentgen Prize]] of the [[Justus-Liebig-University]] of Giessen in 2015.{{cite web|title=Röntgenpreis der JLU geht an Dr. Eleftherios Goulielmakis — Justus-Liebig-Universität Gießen|url=https://www.uni-giessen.de/cms/ueber-uns/pressestelle/pm/pm209-15|website=www.uni-giessen.de|accessdate=December 8, 2015}} == Selected recent works == * [https://www.nature.com/articles/nature16528 “'''Optical attosecond Pulses and probing the response of bound electrons”''' ''Nature '''530''', 66'' (2016)] * '''[http://science.sciencemag.org/content/357/6356/1134 "Soft x-ray Excitonics]'''[http://science.sciencemag.org/content/357/6356/1134 ” ''Science'' '''357''', 1134 (2017)] * [https://www.nature.com/articles/nature14456 “'''Extreme Ultraviolet High Harmonic Spectroscopy of Solids”'''] ''Nature '''521''', 498 (2015) '' * [http://science.sciencemag.org/content/early/2011/09/06/science.1210268 “'''Synthesized Light Transients"''' ''Science'' '''334''', 195 (2011)] * [https://www.nature.com/articles/nature19821 “'''Multi-PHz Electronic Metrology"''' ''Nature'' '''538''', 359 (2016)] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.attoworld.de/goulielmakis-group/ Homepage of the research group Attoelectronics] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goulielmakis, Eleftherios}} [[Category:Greek physicists]] [[Category:University of Crete alumni]] [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Living people]] {{Greece-scientist-stub}} {{Physicist-stub}}

{{Italic title}} {{taxobox | name= ''Flexiviridae'' | virus_group = iv | familia = '''''Flexiviridae''''' | subdivision_ranks = Genera | subdivision = * ''[[Allexivirus]]'' * ''[[Capillovirus]]'' * ''[[Carlavirus]]'' * ''[[Citrivirus]]'' * ''[[Foveavirus]]'' * ''[[Mandarivirus]]'' * ''[[Potexvirus]]'' * ''[[Trichovirus]]'' * ''[[Vitivirus]]'' * '''species unassigned to genera''':
''[[Banana mild mosaic virus]]''
''[[Cherry green ring mottle virus]]''
''[[Cherry necrotic rusty mottle virus]]''
''[[Potato virus T]]''
''[[Sugarcane striate mosaic-associated virus]]'' }} The '''''Flexiviridae''''' were a new family of [[virus]]es in the 2004 classification of viruses, but have since the 2009 classification been split into the three new families ''[[Alphaflexiviridae]]'', ''[[Betaflexiviridae]]'' and ''[[Gammaflexiviridae]]''. These have in turn been subsumed under the new [[Order (biology)|order]] ''[[Tymovirales]]'' along with the old family ''[[Tymoviridae]]'' by the [[International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses]] based on [[Molecular phylogeny|molecular phylogenetic systematic analyses]] of proteins ([[RNA polymerase]] and [[capsid|viral coat]]). The viruses are [[RNA virus|positive-sense ssRNA viruses]], placing them in Group IV of the [[Baltimore classification]]. These viruses are filamentous and named for being highly flexible. Members of these families are readily transmitted mechanically and have other [[Vector (epidemiology)|vectors]] of transmission. Species tend to be confined to a single host plant, many species preferring [[Woody plant|woody]] hosts, but a diversity of [[angiosperm]] hosts are known to the ''Flexiviridae''. Viral aggregates are known to form in the [[cytoplasm]] of [[plant cell]]s.{{cite journal | last = Adams | first = M. J. |author2=J. F. Antoniw |author3=M. Bar-Joseph |author4=A. A. Brunt |author5=T. Candresse |author6=G. D. Foster |author7=G. P. Martelli |author8=R. G. Milne |author9=C. M. Fauquet | title = The new plant virus family Flexiviridae and assessment of molecular criteria for species demarcation | journal = Archives of Virology | volume = 149 | pages = 1045–1060 | publisher = Springer Wien | location = The Netherlands | date = 2004 | doi = 10.1007/s00705-004-0304-0 | accessdate = | pmid = 15098118 | issue = 5 }} ==References== *ICTV Virus Taxonomy 2009 [http://www.ictvonline.org] *UniProt Taxonomy [https://www.uniprot.org/taxonomy/675063] ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090604111324/http://www.expasy.org/viralzone/all_by_species/40.html '''Viralzone''': Flexiviridae] {{Taxonbar|from=Q3813094}} [[Category:Tymovirales]] {{Virus-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=March 2013}}
'''Functional assessment''' is an ongoing process collecting information to understand the reason under a problem or target behavior. The function of the assessment is to prove and aid the effectiveness of the interventions or [[Therapy|treatments]] used to help eliminate the problem behavior. Through functional assessments we have learned that there are complex [[patterns]] to people's seemingly unproductive behaviors. It is important to not only pay attention to consequences that follow the behavior but also the antecedent that [[evokes]] the behavior. More work needs to be done in the future with functional assessment including balancing precision and [[efficiency]], being more specific with variables involved and a more smooth transition from assessment to intervention.<ref name= "JABA">{{cite journal|last=Horner|first=Robert H|title=Functional Assessment: Contributions and Future Directions|journal=Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis|year=1994|volume=27|issue=2|pages=401–404|pmc=1297816|pmid=16795831|doi=10.1901/jaba.1994.27-401 }}</ref>
==Definition== Functional assessment is a method developed by [[applied behavior analysis]] to identify the [[variable (research)|variable]]s that maintain a [[problem]] [[behavior]]. Behavior is [[lawful]]. Whether it is desirable or undesirable, behavior is controlled by environmental variables. Behavior is a function of the [[Antecedent (logic)|antecedent]] and [[Operant conditioning|consequences]] that make up the three-term contingency. Functional assessment is the process of gathering information about the antecedent [[stimulus (psychology)|stimuli]] and consequences functional to the problem behavior. It attempts to provide an explanation to why the problem behavior may be occurring. The information about the antecedent stimuli may include the [[time]] and place, the presence of others and the [[frequency]]. The information collected helps identify which of the antecedent and consequences are maintaining the behavior. The information collected from functional assessment can also help develop appropriate treatments for the target behavior. Stimulus that may have been found to be [[reinforcing]] for the original behavior could be transferred to reinforce a more appropriate behavior.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Harris|first=Sandra L|title=Functional Assessment|journal=Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders|date=April 2003|volume=33|issue=2|pages=233|doi=10.1023/a:1022968200344}}<!--|accessdate=27 July 2012--></ref><ref name= "MMPP">{{cite book|last=Miltenberger|first=Raymond G|title=Behavior Modification Principles & Procedures|year=2012|publisher=Wadsworth, Cengage Learning|location=United States|isbn=978-1-111-30611-3|pages=240–241}}</ref>
==Functions of problem behavior== The purpose of conducting a functional assessment is to identify the function of the target behavior. There are four main classes of functions of problem behavior.<ref name= "Siebert">{{cite journal|last=Siebert|first=Carol|title=Functional Assessment: Process and Product|journal=Home Health Care Management & Practice|date=December 2006|volume=19|issue=1|pages=51–57|url=http://query.library.utoronto.ca/index.php/search/q?kw=functional+assessment&facet[0]=addFacetValueFilters(ContentType,Journal+Article)|accessdate=5 August 2012|doi=10.1177/1084822306292516}}</ref>
===Social positive reinforcement=== Social positive reinforcement is when another person delivers a [[positive reinforcement]] after the problem behavior occurs. This is include the giving of [[attention]], fun activities or goods and services provided by the person. An example of social positive reinforcement would be Max's mother ([[social]]) dropping what she is doing and provide attention (positive reinforcement) to her son when he engages in head banging on the wall (problem behavior).<ref name= "MMPP" />
===Social negative reinforcement=== Social negative reinforcement is when another person delivers a [[negative reinforcement]] after the problem behavior occurs. The person may terminate an aversive stimuli (interaction, task or activity) and the behavior is more likely to be maintained. An example of social negative reinforcement would be Max complains (problem behavior) to his parents (social) when he is asked to do chores, as a result, his parents allows him to escape the task (negative reinforcement).<ref name= "MMPP" />
===Automatic positive reinforcement=== Automatic positive reinforcement is when a positive reinforcement occurs [[Automation|automatically]] and is not mediated by another person. The behavior is strengthened by an automatic reinforcing consequence. An example of automatic positive reinforcement would be an [[autistic]] child waving his hands in front of his face (problem behavior) because the [[sensory perception|sensory]] stimulation (automatic positive reinforcement) produced is reinforcing for the child.<ref name= "MMPP" />
===Automatic negative reinforcement=== Automatic negative reinforcement is when a negative reinforcement occurs automatically reducing or eliminating an aversive stimulus as a reinforcing consequence of the behavior. A popular example of automatic negative reinforcement would be [[binge eating]]. Binge eating (problem behavior) had been found to temporarily reduce any unpleasant emotions the person may be experiencing before the binge (automatic negative reinforcement).<ref name= "MMPP" />
==Assessment methods== There are various different methods used to conduct functional assessment, all of which falls into three distinct categories.<ref name= "Furniss">{{cite journal|last=Furniss|first=Frederick|title=Assessment Methods|journal=Applied Behavior Analysis for Children with Autism Spectrum Disorders|year=2009|volume=10|pages=33–36|doi=10.1007/978-1-4419-0088-3_3}}<!--|accessdate=5 August 2012--></ref>
===Indirect methods=== Indirect functional assessment methods use behavior interviews or surveys to gather information about the person exhibiting the behavior from themselves others who know this person well. The main advantage of indirect methods is they are easy and cheap to conduct and do not take much time. The main disadvantage of indirect methods is that the people involved are relying on their memories, thus some information may be lost or inaccurate.<ref>{{cite web|last=Barribeau|first=Paul|title=Advantages and Disadvantages of the Survey Method|url=http://writing.colostate.edu/guides/research/survey/com2d1.cfm|work=Survey Research. Writing@CSU.|publisher=Colorado State University Department of English.|accessdate=8 August 2012}}</ref>
Because of their convenience, indirect methods are used most commonly. It is essential assessment to be clear and objective as this will produce the most accurate answers without interpretation. The goal of the indirect assessment method is to generate information on the antecedent, behavior and consequence that can help generate a hypothesis about the variables that maintains the behavior.
Indirect methods can help develop a [[correlation]] [[hypothesis]] but not a [[functional relationship]].
===Direct observation methods=== Direct observation methods involve is present to [[observe]] and record the problem behavior as it occurs. The goal of direct observation is to record the immediate antecedent and consequences that functions with the problem behavior within a [[natural environment]]. The main advantage of direct observation is that the antecedents and consequences are recorded as it happens instead of recollection of memory. Therefore, the information recorded is generally more accurate. The main disadvantage of direct observation is it requires a considerable amount of time and effort to implement. Another thing about direct observation is, like indirect methods, it can only demonstrate a correlation but not a functional relationship.<ref name= "Furniss" />
The observer of the direct observation method should be present in the natural environment when the problem behavior is most likely to occur. The observer should also be trained to record the problem behavior and its functional antecedent and consequences immediately, correctly and objectively.
Direct observation can also be can ABC observation. Together with indirect methods, direct and indirect assessments are categorized as descriptive assessment because the antecedent and consequences are described from with memory of events. The information collected aids the development of a hypothesis, but to demonstrate a functional relationship, one must use the experimental method.<ref name= "MMPP" />
===Experimental methods=== Experimental methods involve manipulating either the antecedent or consequent variables to determine their influence on the problem behavior. This is the only method that can demonstrate a functional relationship between the antecedent stimulus or the reinforcing consequence and the problem behavior. The main advantage of the experimental method is the demonstration of a functional relationship. The main disadvantage of the experimental method is the extensive use of time and effort to create an experiment.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hanley|first=Gregory P|author2=Brian A Iwata |author3=Brandon E McCord |title=Functional analysis of problem behavior: a review.|journal=Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis|date=Summer 2003|volume=36|issue=2|pages=146–185|pmc=1284431|pmid=12858983|doi=10.1901/jaba.2003.36-147}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Horner|first=RH|author2=EG Carr |author3=J Halle |author4=G McGee |author5=S Odom |title=The use of single-subject research to identify evidence-based practice in special education|journal=Exceptional children|year=2005|volume=71|issue=2|pages=165|url=http://www.freewebs.com/lowvisionstuff/Single_Subject.pdf|accessdate=8 August 2012 |doi=10.1177/001440290507100203}}</ref>
Experimental methods can also be called experimental analysis or functional analysis.
''For more information please visit [[Functional analysis (psychology)|functional analysis]].''
==Conducting a functional assessment== A functional assessment should always be conducted before treating a problem behavior. To develop appropriate treatment, one must have the correct information about the antecedents and consequences controlling the behavior because treatment involves manipulating these environmental events to evoke a change in the problem behavior. Here is the proper procedure to correctly implement a functional assessment.<ref name= "JABA" />
# The first step should start with a '''behavioral interview''' with the client or someone who knows him/her well. # The interview from the first step should help '''develop a hypothesis''' about which antecedent would produce the behavior and which reinforcing consequence would maintain it. # Once a hypothesis has been formed, the next step is to '''conduct a direct observation assessment''' in the natural environment. If the data collected from the interview is [[consistent]] with the observation, the [[Validity (logic)|validity]] of the hypothesis is strengthened. # With the information from both sources being consistent, '''confirm your initial hypothesis''' to develop appropriate treatment plans for the identified antecedent and consequence. # If the data collected from the behavioral interview and the information observed from the direct observation is inconsistent, '''conduct further assessments''' such as another interview or continued observation to clear up any of the inconsistencies. # If after review and extra interviews and further observations, the information collected are still inconsistent, it is time to '''conduct a functional analysis'''. A functional analysis is also need if the information is consistent but can not lead to a conclusive, firm hypothesis about the [[predictably]] of the antecedent and consequence.<ref name= "MMPP" />
==Functional interventions== After a function assessment has been conducted with success, the information collected is used to develop appropriate treatments and interventions. Interventions are designed to manipulate the antecedent or/and the consequence of the problem behavior to decrease its occurrence rate and increase the rate of occurrence for more desirable behaviors.<ref name= "Siebert" />
Functional interventions include [[extinction]], [[differential reinforcement]] and antecedent manipulations. These intervention are functional because they deal with the environmental events that are functional to the problem behavior. They are also nonaversive as punishment is not involved.<ref name= "MMPP" />
More aversive interventions can be used as latter resort if previous nonaversive intervention have been tried and shown ineffective. Punishment such as [[time-out (parenting)|time-out]] and response cost are considered [[negative punishment]], which although is still controversial, is more widely accepted than [[positive punishment]] such as overcorrection, contingent exercise, guided compliance and [[physical restraint]]. As mentioned punishment should only be used as a last resort when other methods have already been considered.
==Research== A lot of [[research]] being done with functional assessment deals with self injurious behaviors of [[mentally challenged]] children or adults and [[autistic]] children.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Matson|first=Johnny L.|author2=Megan Sipes |author3=Max Horovitz |author4=Julie A. Worley |author5=Mary E. Shoemaker |author6=Alison M. Kozlowski |title=Behaviors and corresponding functions addressed via functional assessment|journal=Research in Developmental Disabilities|date=January 2011|volume=32|issue=2|pages=625–629|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S089142221000301X|accessdate=5 August 2012 |doi=10.1016/j.ridd.2010.12.011}}</ref>
Carr, Newsom and Binkoff conducted an experimental method of functional assessment on the two boys with [[intellectual disabilities]] exhibiting [[aggressive]] behaviors. They hypothesized that their aggressive behaviors were maintained by escape from academic tasks. To test their hypothesis, they set two different experimental conditions; 1. Academic demands were put on the boys, 2. Academic demands were not put on the children. If their hypothesis is true, then the problem behavior should occur much more often in the first condition than the second. Results show that their hypothesis was indeed true as the aggressive behavior occurred at a much higher frequency in the first condition. The researchers concluded that the boy's problem behavior was indeed maintained by the antecedent of academic demands and the consequence of escape from the demands.
Another functional assessment research was done by Iwata in 1982 worked with children with [[developmental disabilities]] showing self injurious behaviors. The research could not conclude what was maintaining their behavior but believed it either adult attention, escape from demands or [[Sensory system|sensory]] stimulation from the injuries. For each of the hypothesis, they created a condition that would fit into the category. For adult attention hypothesis, they created an environment where an adult is in the room with the child but pays no attention to him/her until after the behavior occurs. For the escape from demands hypothesis, they had an adult make a normal demand towards the child, but terminate it if the self injurious behavior occurs. For the sensory stimulation hypothesis, the child is left alone without the presence of anyone or any stimulating activities. Iwata compared the levels of self injurious behaviors across the three conditions and demonstrated that the function of the problem behavior for each child was different. Some wanted attention, others escape while some were maintained by automatic reinforcement. As shown here, it is very important to conduct a functional assessment to determine what exactly is maintaining the behavior before any function interventions are taken.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Iwata|first=Brian A|author2=Michael F. Dorseya |author3=Keith J. Slifera |author4=Kenneth E. Baumana |author5=Gina S. Richmana |title=Toward a functional analysis of self-injury|journal=Analysis and Intervention in Developmental Disabilities|year=1982|volume=2|issue=1|pages=3–20|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0270468482900039|accessdate=7 August 2012|doi=10.1016/0270-4684(82)90003-9|pmc=1297798}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Behavior modification]] * [[Functional analysis]] * [[Extinction]] * [[Behavioral targeting]]

{{Infobox scientist |name = Gisela Mosig |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|1930|11|29|mf=yes}} |birth_place = [[Saxony]], [[Germany]] |nationality = Germany
United States |death_date = {{death date and age|2003|1|12|1930|11|29|mf=yes}} |death_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. |field = [[Molecular genetics]] |known_for = Molecular biology of [[enterobacteria phage T4]] }} '''Gisela Mosig''' (November 29, 1930 – January 12, 2003) was a German-American [[molecular biologist]] best known for her work with [[enterobacteria phage T4]]. She was among the first investigators to recognize the importance of [[Genetic recombination|recombination]] intermediates in establishing new [[DNA replication#Replication fork|DNA replication forks]], a fundamental process in DNA replication.{{Cite journal|last=Syeda|first=Aisha H.|last2=Hawkins|first2=Michelle|last3=McGlynn|first3=Peter|date=2014-10-23|title=Recombination and replication|journal=Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Biology|volume=6|issue=11|pages=a016550|doi=10.1101/cshperspect.a016550|issn=1943-0264|pmc=4413237|pmid=25341919}} ==Early years== While growing up on a farm in [[Saxony]], Mosig became interested in biology and physics.{{cite web|title=Pioneering genetic researcher Gisela Mosig dies|date=January 24, 2003|url=http://www.mc.vanderbilt.edu/reporter/index.html?ID=2484|website=Vanderbilt Reporter|publisher=Vanderbilt University Medical Center|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}{{cite journal|last1=Nossal|first1=NG|last2=Franklin|first2=JL|last3=Kutter|first3=E|last4=Drake|first4=JW|title=Gisela Mosig|journal=Genetics|date=November 2004|volume=168|issue=3|pages=1097–104|pmid=15579671|series=Anecdotal, historical and critical commentaries on genetics|pmc=1448779}} After [[World War II]] (when she was 14 years old), the region where she lived became part of [[East Germany]] and evolutionary teaching in her high school skewed toward [[Lysenkoism]]. Finding the intellectual atmosphere intolerable, she fled to the west on her bicycle with only the belongings she could carry. After undergraduate studies at the [[University of Bonn]], she earned her doctoral degree in plant genetics at the [[University of Cologne]] in 1959. From there, she was recruited to Vanderbilt University to study [[bacteriophage T4]], a topic for which she became a leading investigator. After postdoctoral research at Vanderbilt and then the [[Carnegie Institution for Science|Carnegie Institute of Washington at Cold Spring Harbor]] (with Nobel laureate [[Alfred Hershey|A. D. Hershey]]), she returned to Vanderbilt as a faculty member in 1965, and became a citizen of the [[United States of America]] in 1968. Mosig served on the Vanderbilt faculty until her death in 2003. ==Recognition== * Outstanding Graduate Teaching Award (Vanderbilt, 1989){{cite web|title=Faculty and Graduate Student Awards|url=http://as.vanderbilt.edu/faculty/awards.php|website=Faculty and Graduate Student Awards|publisher=Vanderbilt University|accessdate=January 16, 2017}} * Elected Fellow of the [[American Society for Microbiology#American Academy of Microbiology|American Academy of Microbiology]] (1994) * Earl Sutherland Prize for Achievement in Research (Vanderbilt, 1995){{cite web|title=Earl Sutherland Prize for Achievement in Research|url=http://www.vanderbilt.edu/provost/faculty-highlights/earl-sutherland.php|website=www.vanderbilt.edu|publisher=lt University Office of the Provost|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} ==Death== Mosig died at [[Alive Hospice]] in Nashville a few years after being diagnosed with metastatic [[ovarian cancer]]. She was 72 years old. In her will she endowed a fund to support scholarly travel for Vanderbilt graduate students in the biological sciences.Brasher, Joan. [https://news.vanderbilt.edu/archived-news/register/articles/index-id=6893.html Mosig bequest example of way to support research] Vanderbilt Register, October 10, 2003. ==Key publications== * {{cite journal|last1='''Mosig'''|first1=G|title=A map of distances along the DNA molecule of phage T4.|journal=Genetics|date=June 1968|volume=59|issue=2|pages=137–51|pmid=5702346|pmc=1211937}} * {{cite journal|last1=Luder|first1=A|last2='''Mosig'''|first2=G|title=Two alternative mechanisms for initiation of DNA replication forks in bacteriophage T4: priming by RNA polymerase and by recombination.|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date=February 1982|volume=79|issue=4|pages=1101–5|pmid=7041114|pmc=345908|doi=10.1073/pnas.79.4.1101}} * {{cite book|last1=Mathews|first1=Christoper K.|last2=Kutter|first2=Elizabeth M.|last3='''Mosig'''|first3=Gisela|last4=Berget|first4=Peter B.|title=Bacteriophage T4|date=1983|publisher=American Soc. for Microbiology|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=0914826565}} * {{cite journal|last1='''Mosig'''|first1=G|title=The essential role of recombination in phage T4 growth|journal=Annual Review of Genetics|date=1987|volume=21|pages=347–71|doi=10.1146/annurev.ge.21.120187.002023|pmid=3327469}} * {{cite journal|last1='''Mosig'''|first1=G|title=Recombination and recombination-dependent DNA replication in bacteriophage T4|journal=Annual Review of Genetics|date=1998|volume=32|pages=379–413|doi=10.1146/annurev.genet.32.1.379|pmid=9928485}} * {{cite journal|last1=Miller|first1=ES|last2=Kutter|first2=E|last3='''Mosig'''|first3=G|last4=Arisaka|first4=F|last5=Kunisawa|first5=T|last6=Rüger|first6=W|title=Bacteriophage T4 genome|journal=Microbiology and molecular biology reviews: MMBR|date=March 2003|volume=67|issue=1|pages=86–156|pmid=12626685|pmc=150520|doi=10.1128/mmbr.67.1.86-156.2003}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{Orphan|date=January 2017}}
'''HST events''', things of interest related to the [[Hubble Space Telescope]], chronologically.
==2018== *Hubble takes a panormaic ultraviolet light view of over 15,000 thousand galaxies (part of Hubble Deep UV (HDUV) Legacy Survey).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://spacecoastdaily.com/2018/08/nasas-hubble-space-telescope-captures-largest-panoramic-views-of-star-birth-in-distant-universe/|title=NASA's Hubble Space Telescope Captures Largest Panoramic Views of Star Birth In Distant Universe {{!}}|website=spacecoastdaily.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref>
==2013== *Hubble found evidence of water jets on Jupiter's moon [[Europa (moon)|Europa]].<ref>[http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/news/display.cfm?News_ID=45832 Hubble Space Telescope Sees Evidence of Water Vapor Venting off Jupiter Moon]</ref> *Hubble finds and asteroid spouting comet-Like tails.<ref>[http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/news/display.cfm?News_ID=45431 NASA's Hubble Sees Asteroid Spouting Six Comet-Like Tails]</ref> *Hubble found a new moon of [[Neptune]] in July 2013.<ref>[http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/news/display.cfm?News_ID=44290 NASA - Hubble Finds New Neptune Moon]</ref>
==2012== *Hubble detects a fifth satellite for Pluto.<ref>[http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/news/display.cfm?News_ID=39884 Hubble Discovers a Fifth Moon Orbiting Pluto]</ref>
==2011== *Hubble finds evidence for fourth Pluto satellite.<ref>[http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/news/display.cfm?News_ID=39884 NASA's Hubble Discovers Another Moon Around Pluto]</ref>
==1997== *NICMOS installed by a Space Shuttle servicing mission.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hubblesite.org/the_telescope/nuts_.and._bolts/instruments/nicmos/|title=HubbleSite - NICMOS|website=hubblesite.org|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref>
==1990== *Hubble launched on April 24, 1990 with the shuttle mission [[STS-31]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-31/mission-sts-31.html |title=STS-31 |publisher=NASA |accessdate= April 26, 2008}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Hubble Space Telescope]]

page.title: Jacques Sébastien François Léonce Marie Paul Fagot

revision.text:
'''Jacques Sébastien François Léonce Marie Paul Fagot''' (1842–1908) was a French [[malacologist]] who often published under the name '''Paul Fagot.'''<ref name="simon">Saint-Simon, Guillaume Camille Alfred de Candie de (1885). ''Miscellanées Malacologiques.'' Toulouse, France </ref>
==Life and career==
Fagot was part of a "New School" of [[naturalist]]s, which included [[Jules-René Bourguignat]], [[Aristide-Horace Letourneux]], [[ Jules François Mabille]], and [[ Étienne Alexandre Arnould Locard]]. Species of [[land snail]]s that were named and described by Fagot include ''[[Aegopinella epipedostoma]]'', ''[[Pyrenaearia navasi]]'', and ''[[Pyrenaearia cotiellae]]''.<ref name="caziot">Caziot C (1908). Nécrologie. Paul Fagot. ''Journal de Conchy''</ref><ref name="hesse">Hesse P (1910). Necrologie. ''Nachrichtsblatt der Deutschen Malakozoologisc''</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.malacological.org/pdfs/2400years/2400yrs_of_Malacology-part_2.pdf Paul Fagot profile] via [[American Malacological Society]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fagot, Jacques Sebastien Francois}} [[Category:1842 births]] [[Category:1908 deaths]]
{{Biologist-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Katharine Bement Davis | image = Katharine Bement Davis in 1915.jpg | alt = | caption = Davis in 1913 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1860|01|15}} | birth_place = [[Buffalo, New York]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1935|12|10|1860|01|15}} | death_place = [[Pacific Grove, California]] | nationality = | education = Rochester Free Academy | alma_mater = [[Vassar College]], [[Barnard College]], [[Chicago University]] (first female Fellow in Political Science-Economics to earn a Ph.D.) | other_names = | occupation = [[Progressive era]] social reformer and [[criminologist]] | employer = Dunkirk Academy, Brooklyn Heights Seminary for Girls, Philadelphia's College Settlement House, [[New York State Reformatory for Women]], [[New York City Department of Correction]], New York City [[Bureau of Social Hygiene]] | organization = | known_for = [[Correction Commissioner]]; the first woman to head a major [[New York City]] agency; research in [[Human female sexuality|female sexuality]] | awards = Designated "one of the three most distinguished women in America" by the [[Panama-Pacific Exposition]]; honorary degrees from [[Mount Holyoke College]], [[Western Reserve University|Western Reserve]] and [[Yale]] | children = | parents = Oscar Bill Davis and Frances Freeman | relatives = Two brothers, two sisters }}
'''Katharine Bement Davis''' (January 15, 1860 – December 10, 1935) was an American [[progressive era]] [[Reform movement|social reformer]] and [[criminologist]] who became the first woman to head a major [[New York City]] agency when she was appointed [[Correction Commissioner]] on January 1, 1914.<ref name="McCarthy">{{cite book|last=McCarthy|first=Thomas C. |title=New York City's Suffragist Commissioner: Correction's Katherine Bement Davis |publisher=[[New York City Department of Correction]]|location=New York, New York|year=1997|url=|accessdate=6 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Dr. Katherine Bement Davis Talks of Her Hopes for Bettering Conditions |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C02EFDF1E39E633A25752C1A9679C946596D6CF |quote=Miss Katharine Bement Davis, who has been appointed Commissioner of Correction by Mayor Mitchel, is a very earnest woman. Her work at Bedford Reformatory, of which something was told in The Times a year ago, showed that, and it also proved her able. |work=[[New York Times]] |date= January 11, 1914|accessdate=2010-07-22 | first=Edward | last=Marshall}}</ref><ref name=bedford>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |quote=Miss Katherine Bement Davis, who has been appointed Commissioner of Correction by Mayor Mitchel, is a very earnest woman. Her work at Bedford Reformatory, of which something was told in The Times a year ago, showed that, and it also proved her able. |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F3081EFE355D13738DDDA80994D9405B848DF1D3 |title=New York's First Woman Commissioner Of Correction. Dr. Katherine Bement Davis Talks of Her Hopes for Bettering Conditions. The Tombs an Awful Problem to Face. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=January 11, 1914 |accessdate=2010-10-05 }}</ref>
The [[Panama-Pacific Exposition]] designated her one of the three most distinguished women in America.<ref name="McCarthy" /><ref name="Problems Women Solved">{{cite book|last=Simpson|first=Greg Ed. |title=Problems Women Solved: Being the Story of the Woman's Board of the Panama-Pacific International Exposition|publisher=Read Books|year=2008|pages=130|isbn=1-4437-4498-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dMNI7tzUXPcC&pg=PA130&lpg=PA130&dq=Panama+Pacific+International+Exposition+Katharine+Davis&source=bl&ots=v1684zx_tX&sig=KIDJCwQr7Q7XpKoZMCJ8kzVfKAY&hl=en&ei=xC6US6HSBIz0sgOtiJH9Aw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=&f=false|accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref> Davis is remembered for her pioneering science-based prison reform and groundbreaking research about [[Human female sexuality|female sexuality]].<ref name="McCarthy" />
==Biography== She was born in [[Buffalo, New York]], on January 15, 1860, to Oscar Bill Davis and Frances Freeman. She was the oldest of five children—three girls and two boys.<ref name="McCarthy" /><ref name="More Than Petticoats">{{cite book|last=Petrash|first=Antonia |title=More Than Petticoats: Remarkable New York Women|publisher=The Globe Pequot Press|year=2002|pages=92|accessdate=6 March 2010}}</ref> Katharine's mother Frances was a strong proponent of women's rights and a zealous advocate for women's [[suffrage]].<ref name="More Than Petticoats" />
The Davis family lived in [[Dunkirk, New York]], during most of her childhood. Both of her parents were active in community organizations in Dunkirk.<ref name="More Than Petticoats" /> Oscar Davis worked for Bradstreet company, and when Katharine was seventeen he relocated to [[Rochester, New York]], to manage a regional office there.<ref name="McCarthy" /><ref name="More Than Petticoats" />
===Education and early careers=== In 1879, Davis graduated from Rochester Free Academy, a public high school. Since her family was unable to afford the tuition for college, she taught at Dunkirk Academy. While at Dunkirk Academy, she established a women's equality club and led a women's literacy group.<ref name="McCarthy" />
After teaching [[General chemistry|high school chemistry]] for ten years, Davis saved enough money to continue her schooling full-time. In 1890, she enrolled in [[Vassar College]], a center of progressive education for women. Davis combined her interests in science and [[social reform]] by studying food chemistry and nutritional studies. Taking this course of study gave Davis the opportunity for career in a [[public health]] agency after graduation.<ref name="McCarthy" />
After graduating from Vassar, Davis continued her studies at [[Columbia University]]'s [[Barnard College]], a separate women's college within the university, while teaching at Brooklyn Heights Seminary for Girls. She studied the chemistry of food.
While studying at Barnard, Davis managed a project to develop a model home for New York State's display at the [[World's Columbian Exposition|Chicago World Fair]]. As a result of the success of the home display, she was offered a job running a [[settlement house]] in [[Philadelphia]].<ref name="McCarthy" />
===Philadelphia's College Settlement House=== The [[settlement house]] movement began in the late 19th century to socialize the poor and uneducated residents that occupied immigrant neighborhoods in a city to American values and customs. In the United States, "college settlements" were run by young women graduates of progressive colleges who as "workers" moved into a neighborhood house in order to Americanize the local residents.<ref name="The enduring vision: a history of the American people">{{cite book|last=Boyer|first=Paul S. |title=The enduring vision: a history of the American people|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=2008|pages=581|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SoR98M6c-t0C&pg=PA581&dq=settlement+house+movement&num=30&client=firefox-a&cd=2#v=onepage&q=settlement%20house%20movement&f=false|accessdate=7 March 2010 | isbn=978-0-618-80159-6}}</ref>
The College Settlement on Philadelphia's St. Mary's Street served a district of indigent blacks and Russian immigrants. Davis moved into the house as "head worker". While in Philadelphia, Davis worked with [[W. E. B. Du Bois]], who was then at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] conducting groundbreaking research on blacks in urban America. Davis noted in the Settlement's annual report that "the investigation into the condition of the colored people of . . . the seventh ward which contains about 10,000 Negroes, nearly one fourth the entire number in the city" would be carried out "by means of house-to-house canvass."<ref name="McCarthy" />
===Chicago=== Davis moved to [[Chicago, Illinois]] to return to school at [[Chicago University]] where she was to be the first female Fellow in Political Science-Economics to earn a Ph.D.
==Corrections career==
===Bedford Hills Reformatory=== The [[New York State Reformatory for Women]] at [[Bedford Hills, New York]] opened in May 1901 with Davis as the superintendent.<ref name=bedford/> Besides the administration building, the campus included "a reception hall, four cottages, a laundry building, a powerhouse, a gate house, and a stable". The reception hall had two wings, one wing modeled after a traditional prison with three tiers of 24 cells each, and the other wing contained rooms accommodating 42 inmates.<ref name="McCarthy" />
===Pre-sentencing evaluations=== In 1909 Davis arranged for the [[New York Public Education Association]] to do a psychological testing study at Bedford. The results showed that serious mental problems existed in a significant number of the female inmates. This result indicated a disconnect between the original focus of the reformatory and the population of inmates that it was serving. In 1910 Davis advocated for judges to have access to pre-sentencing background research and evaluations so that they can made appropriate placements. Davis wrote up her ideas in a pamphlet, ''A Rational Plan for the Treatment of Women Convicted in the Courts of New York City.'' that was widely distributed to people affiliated with criminal justice system in New York City.<ref name="McCarthy" />
The Prison Association of New York recognized the reforms that Davis made at Bedford Hills saying that "the reformatory is becoming perhaps the most scientific institution of its kind in the world."<ref name="McCarthy" />
Reform-minded Mayor [[John Purroy Mitchel]] selected Davis to head the Correction Commission making her the first woman to lead an agency in New York City on January 1, 1914.<ref name="McCarthy" /><ref name=bedford/> Based on her relationship with Mitchel and his associates, Davis was on the Progressive party's 1914 slate for State Constitutional Convention seat, making her the first woman to run for a New York statewide office on a major party ticket.<ref name="McCarthy" />
==Bureau of Social Hygiene== The [[Bureau of Social Hygiene]] in New York City was an agency incorporated by [[John D. Rockefeller, Jr.]] in 1913 for "the study, amelioration, and prevention of those social conditions, crimes, and diseases which adversely affect the well-being of society, with special reference to [[Prostitution in the United States|prostitution]] and the evils associated therewith."<ref name="Rockefeller-Related Organization Archives">{{cite web|url=http://www.rockarch.org/collections/rockorgs/bsh.php|title=Bureau Of Social Hygiene Archives, 1911-1940|location=Sleepy Hollow, New York|work=Rockefeller-Related Organization Archives|publisher=The Rockefeller Archive Center|accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref> Rockefeller established the agency as a result of his appointment in 1911 to a special grand jury to investigate [[prostitution|white slavery]] in New York City. The Bureau's work was influenced by the view that there was a biological basis for crime. During the Bureau's early years the main focus was on prostitution, [[vice]], and [[political corruption]]. During later years, the Bureau shifted its emphasis towards criminology and the control of crime. The Bureau stopped granting new appropriations in 1934, and by 1937 all prior commitments were completed.<ref name="Rockefeller-Related Organization Archives"/>
In 1918 Davis became the head of the Bureau.<ref name="McCarthy"/>
===Sexuality research=== At the Bureau of Social Hygiene, Davis arranged for ground-breaking research on women's sexuality on "normal" females. These were women whose names were found from club memberships directories and college alumnae lists. They were surveyed about "auto-erotic practices, the frequency of sexual desire, homosexual experiences, use of contraceptives, frequency of sexual intercourse, pre-marital and extra-marital sexual experiences."<ref name="McCarthy" /><ref name="Electronic Journal of Human Sexuality">{{cite journal|last=Owens|first=Annette Fuglsang |date=July 25, 2000|title=Book Review|journal=Electronic Journal of Human Sexuality|volume=3|url=http://www.ejhs.org/volume3/book7.htm|accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref>
===Eugenics=== [[Compulsory sterilization]] was seen by many as a way to reduce the incidence of [[mental illness]] and [[mental retardation]] in the general population of the United States. Davis was an [[eugenicist]] and during her tenure as General Secretary, she affiliated the Bureau with leaders in the field of [[eugenics]] such as [[Harry Laughlin]], [[Charles Davenport]] and [[E. S. Gosney]], director of The Human Betterment Foundation in California. In 1924, Davis accepted a position on the Committee on Eugenics of the United States' Advisory Council.<ref name="The Mendel Newsletter">{{cite web|url=http://www.ferris.edu/HTMLS/othersrv/isar/archives2/sources/bsh.htm|title=Sources in the Study of Eugenics #2: The Bureau of Social Hygiene|last=Mehler|first=Barry |date=September 1978|work=The Mendel Newsletter|publisher=Institute for the Study of Academic Racism at Ferris State University|pages=No. 16|accessdate=7 March 2010|location=Big Rapids, Missouri}}</ref>
===Retirement=== At the end of 1927 her contract was not extended and she retired. On February 2, 1928, the [[Waldorf-Astoria]] ballroom was filled with Progressive Era reformers to honor Davis at a testimonial dinner. The guests including [[Eleanor Roosevelt]], [[Jane Addams]], [[Carrie Chapman Catt]], Rev. [[Harry Emerson Fosdick]], [[Walter Lippman]], Judge [[William McAdoo (New Jersey)|William McAdoo]], [[John D. Rockefeller Jr.]], [[Lillian Wald]] and [[Felix Warburg]].<ref name="McCarthy" />
==Later life, death, and legacy== Davis retired to Pacific Grove, California with her sisters. Davis died December 10, 1935 from [[cerebral arteriosclerosis]] at her home.<ref name="McCarthy"/>
During her lifetime Davis was honored numerous times by a variety of organizations. The [[Panama-Pacific Exposition]] designated her one of the three most distinguished women in America.<ref name="Problems Women Solved"/> Davis received honorary degrees from [[Mount Holyoke College]], [[Western Reserve University|Western Reserve]] and [[Yale]] universities.<ref name="McCarthy"/>
==Selected works== * (1925) ''A Study of Certain Auto-Erotic Practices''
==See also== *''[[The End of the Road (1919 film)|The End of the Road]]'' (1919)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Davis, Katharine Bement}} [[Category:American eugenicists]] [[Category:American suffragists]] [[Category:American criminologists]] [[Category:Vassar College alumni]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:Barnard College alumni]] [[Category:Science teachers]] [[Category:American schoolteachers]] [[Category:Scientists from Buffalo, New York]] [[Category:Scientists from New York City]] [[Category:1860 births]] [[Category:1935 deaths]] [[Category:People from Dunkirk, New York]] [[Category:Social reformers]] [[Category:20th-century American writers]] [[Category:20th-century American women writers]] [[Category:Activists from Buffalo, New York]]

page.title: List of U.S. state and territory mottos

revision.comment: Changed "Eius" in Puerto Rico's motto to "Ejus" to be in line with the official spelling.
revision.text:
[[File:Seal of California.svg|thumb|upright|''[[Eureka (word)|Eureka]]'', the motto of [[California]] on [[Seal of California|its state seal]]]] [[File:Seal of Colorado.svg|thumb|upright|''[[Nil sine numine]]'', the motto of [[Colorado]] on [[Seal of Colorado|its state seal]]]] [[File:Seal of Florida.svg|thumb|upright|[[In God We Trust]], the motto of [[Florida]] on [[Seal of Florida|its state seal]]]] [[File:2008 HI Proof.png|thumb|upright|''[[Ua Mau ke Ea o ka ʻĀina i ka Pono]]'', the motto of [[Hawaii]] on its [[50 State Quarters|state quarter]]]] [[File:2007 ID Proof Rev.png|thumb|upright|''[[Esto perpetua]]'', the motto of [[Idaho]] on its [[50 State Quarters|state quarter]]]] [[File:2002 IN Proof.png|thumb|upright|Crossroads of America, the motto of [[Indiana]] on its [[50 State Quarters|state quarter]]]] [[File:Seal of Kansas.svg|thumb|upright|[[Ad astra per aspera]], the motto of [[Kansas]] on [[Seal of Kansas|its state seal]]]] [[File:2000 NH Proof.png|thumb|upright|[[Live free or die]], the motto of [[New Hampshire]] on its [[50 State Quarters|state quarter]]]] [[File:Seal of South Carolina.svg|thumb|upright|[[South Carolina]] has two state mottos]] [[File:2001 VT Proof.png|thumb|upright|[[Freedom and Unity]], the motto of [[Vermont]] on its [[50 State Quarters|state quarter]]]] All of the [[United States]]' 50 [[U.S. state|states]] have a state [[motto]], as do the [[District of Columbia]] and three [[territories of the United States|US territories]]. A motto is a phrase intended to formally describe the general motivation or intention of an organization. State mottos can sometimes be found on [[Seals of the U.S. states|state seals]] or [[Flags of the U.S. states|state flags]]. Some states have officially designated a state motto by an act of the [[State legislature (United States)|state legislature]], whereas other states have the motto only as an element of their seals. The motto of the United States itself is ''[[In God We Trust]]'', proclaimed by Congress and signed into law by President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] on July 30, 1956.{{cite web|url=http://www.treas.gov/education/fact-sheets/currency/in-god-we-trust.shtml|title=History of 'In God we Trust'|publisher=U.S. Treasury|accessdate=2009-02-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228174920/http://www.treas.gov/education/fact-sheets/currency/in-god-we-trust.shtml|archivedate=2009-02-28|df=}} The motto ''[[E Pluribus Unum]]'' (Latin for "One from many") was approved for use on the Great Seal of the United States in 1782, but was never adopted as the national motto through legislative action. [[South Carolina]] has two official mottos, both of which are in Latin. Kentucky, North Dakota, and Vermont also have two mottos, one in Latin and the other in English.{{cite web|url=http://www.nd.gov/content.htm?parentCatID=74&id=State%20Coat%20of%20Arms|title=State Coat of Arms|publisher=State of North Dakota|accessdate=2016-10-02}} All other states and territories have only one motto, except Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands, which do not have any mottos. [[English language|English]] and [[Latin]] are the most-used languages for state mottos, each used by 25 states and territories. Seven states and territories use another language, of which each language is only used once. Eight states and two territories have their mottos on their [[50 State Quarters|state quarter]]; thirty-eight states and four territories have their mottos on their state seals. The dates given are, where possible, the earliest date that the motto was used in an official sense. Some state mottos are not official but are on the official state seal; in these cases the adoption date of the seal is given. The earliest use of a current motto is that of [[Puerto Rico]], ''Johannes est nomen ejus'', granted to the island by the Spanish in 1511. ==State and territory mottos== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" !width=4%|State/Territory !width=11%|Motto !class="unsortable" width=9%|English Translation !width=3%|Language !width=2%|Date !class="unsortable" width=1%|Ref. |-
